awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Scalable Machine Learning for Genome-Wide Association Analyses
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past decade, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have discovered genetic variants associated with numerous diseases as well as other complex phenotypes. Despite their success, major gaps remain in our understanding of how genetic changes affect phenotype. These gaps, coupled with advances in high-throughput technologies to measure genetic variation, have motivated GWAS of increasingly larger scale. However, the statistical and computational challenges posed by the scale and complexity of these studies present a critical bottleneck in realizing their promise.  These recent advances in scalable ML provide the potential for paradigm-shifting advances in the field of GWAS. However, these concepts have yet to be rigorously explored in the context of the GWAS modeling and testing problems. Exploring the intersection of these domains introduces fundamentally new statistical and computational challenges. The team will develop a suite of modeling and testing methods that target massive modern genomics datasets. The techniques that we will build upon include low-rank matrix approximation, kernel methods and matrix completion. They will also provide open-source software tailored to parallel and distributed computing environments to facilitate wide-spread adoption of methods.



Exploring GWAS through the lens of scalable machine learning introduces several research directions and requires the development of novel algorithms and analyses. Firstly, the focus of much scalable ML research has been on the statistical task of prediction, while GWAS inference problems also emphasize hypothesis testing and parameter estimation. Characterizing the behavior of scalable ML methods in these novel settings is a challenging open problem. The team will develop principled GWAS modeling and testing methods. The results to also be of great interest to the scalable ML community. Secondly, while scalable ML techniques are designed to be general purpose and domain-agnostic, the GWAS setting introduces rich biologically-motivated domain knowledge that needs to be leveraged to improve the quality of inference. Statistical models that are able to encode this prior knowledge while still permitting efficient inference will be developed. Ultimately the algorithms will be implemented as efficient parallel and distributed algorithms for these core modeling and testing problems, and develop robust open-source implementations that leverage modern computing infrastructure.1The proposed methods will dramatically improve the scalability of current GWAS analyses, on the one hand, while enabling the development of increasingly realistic genomic models, on the other. Collaborations and open-source artifacts will enable the wide-spread adoption of these methods by the human genetics community. This project will lead to a closer interaction of the genomics and machine learning communities at UCLA and outside.

por.por_cntn:
Our project proposes to leverage techniques from the field of scalable machine learning (scalable ML) to develop principled inference approaches to two core problems in GWAS: modeling how genetic variants modulates phenotypic variation (including risk for disease) and in detecting genetic variants that modulate specific phenotype. We have made substantial progress on both of these goals. Overall, we have published a total of 27 papers published in top ML conferences (ICML, AISTATS), computational Biology conferences (RECOMB) as well as in high-impact journals (American Journal of Human Genetics, PLoS Genetics, Nature Communications, Nature Genetics). We briefly summarize the outcomes and findings of our work:

Intellectual merit: Heritability, the proportion of variation in a phenotype that is explained by genetic variation, is a fundamental quantity in the study of complex traits. While a number of methods have been developed for estimating heritability from genotype data collected on unrelated individuals, these methods have difficulty in scaling to large-scale genomic datasets that are now being collected (containing hundreds of thousands of individuals at millions of genetic variants). We have developed a class of algorithms that can accurately and efficiently estimate heritability across these large datasets (Wu et al. Bioinformatics 2018). We have then expanded the applicability of these algorithms across an increasing range of models (Pazokitoroudi et al. Nature Communications 2020, Wu et al. American Journal of Human Genetics 2022). Further, applications of our methods have revealed new biological aspects of the mechanisms underlying how genetic variation impacts phenotypes.

Understanding the hidden or latent structure in genomic data is another fundamental analytical task. Existing approaches for inferring structure rely on techniques such as Principal component analysis (PCA) or admixture models. With the advent of large-scale datasets of genetic variation, there is a need for methods that can compute principal components (PCs) with scalable computational and memory requirements. We first developed ProPCA, a highly scalable method based on a probabilistic generative model, which computes the top PCs on genetic variation data efficiently (Agrawal, Chiu et al. PLoS Genetics 2020). We then built on these ideas to develop SCOPE, a method for population structure inference that is orders of magnitude faster than existing methods while achieving comparable accuracy (Chiu et al. AJHG 2022).

A key consideration in applying ML models to biology is a need for the inferences to be interpretable. We have developed methods for interpreting complex ML models that are tailored for biological applications (Plumb et al. ICML 2020). We expect these methods to become increasingly important with the adoption and application of ML in biology.

Broader impact: Our methods have found interest across diverse intellectual communities spanning ML, computational biology, and genomics communities. We have also made all of our methods available as open-source software. Our methods have already been utilized by groups working with large-scale genomic datasets to obtain novel insights. These methods have also catalyzed collaborations with groups that are analyzing these datasets in the context of specific phenotypes and diseases. Further, several groups that develop computational methods have built new methods that leverage our software and have extended the ideas described in our papers. We expect the impact of our work to grow as the size and complexity of genomic datasets grow. 

This project has provided training and professional development opportunities to multiple graduate students and has allowed them obtain direct experience engaging with machine learning, genomics and interdisciplinary research. The project has also provided mentoring for undergraduate students at the intersection of ML and genomics (and opportunities for graduate students to mentor undergraduate students). Both PIs have continued to perform outreach across the ML and genomics communities through venues such as the MLSys conference and the Computational Genomics Summer Institute as ways of fostering close interactions among ML and genomics communities. Finally, the PIs have developed graduate classes aimed at training students in ML and genomics and to expose them to research in the field.
